Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Hide package metadata for certain packages" (#9096) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The package details will be hidden for certain packages which are unlisted, locked and if any of the owner is locked.

Spec: https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/pull/4257

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Removing tests that are feature-flag-state-dependent." (#9094) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: `/packages` request produces 400 for the test only if the code path that analyzes the content of `nugetab` cookie is executed (i.e. A/B testing feature flag is enabled). When it is not, the cookie is completely ignored and tests that involve it fail. We don't need that feature flag dependency in tests that are gateway for the deployment, hence the removal.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Merge branch 'main' into dev" (#9095) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: This makes dev branch CG compliant.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Test-SimpleBindingRedirectsClassLibraryReference fails against Dev17 with Exception message: Element not found. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8002802B (TYPE_E_ELEMENTNOTFOUND))" (#10890) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The TYPE_E_ELEMENTNOTFOUND happens while adding a ProjectReference from the New-WebSite project to one of the New-ClassLibrary projects. The line is:

`Add-ProjectReference` $b $e

Disabling this test for now so we can proceed with the merge of release-6.0.x into dev.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Re-enable F# tests" (#11672) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Re-enable F# tests skipped due to https://github.com/dotnet/fsharp/issues/12835

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Option to migrate package references from a project to Directory.Packages.props" (#11753) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### The Elevator Pitch

The new Directory.Packages.props feature is a great way of having a central place to specify package versions to use throughout a solution. For existing solutions that have multiple projects and as much packages installed, going through the csproj files to migrate them over to the Directory.Packages.props file could be quite a time-consuming task.

So it would be great if we could "migrate" packages from a project to this file. For example, there could be a "Move to Directory.Packages.props file" option accessed from the context menu on the installed package in the solution explorer that would create an entry into the Directory.Packages.props file and remove the version from the one in the csproj (or only the last part if the package was already in the props file.

In cases where the version would differ from the one in the props file, a prompt could confirm if we wish to overwrite with the selected version, use the one from the props file, or cancel

There are probably cases I didn't cover, but the general idea is there and I'm sure we'd benefit from having this option.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Epic]: Additional central package management features for the next release" (#11752) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
These items need to be addressed to make central package management production ready.

## Performance
Take performance measurements for large repositories to ensure that there is no regression in restore times.  Also look for any optimizations that can be made.

- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10256
- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9740
- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9740

## Features
Add additional requested features and ease migration pain when migrating to NuGet's CPM from implementations like Microsoft.Build.CentralPackageVersions.

- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10159
  [Microsoft.Build.CentralPackageVersions](https://github.com/microsoft/MSBuildSdks/tree/main/src/CentralPackageVersions) has this handy "global" package feature that is syntactic sugar for adding a package reference to every project in the tree.  It essentially turns this:  
  ```xml
     <GlobalPackageReference Include="Some.Build.Package" Version="1.0.0" />
  ```
  Into this:
  ```xml
      <PackageReference Include="Some.Build.Package" Version="1.0.0" IncludeAssets="Analyzers,Build" PrivateAssets="All" />
  ```
  Which ensures that "global" package references are only used for build logic and don't spill into upstream dependencies.  These kind of packages are just used by every project in the repository but aren't a compile-time asset.
  Having this feature in NuGet's CPM will greatly ease migrations from [Microsoft.Build.CentralPackageVersions](https://github.com/microsoft/MSBuildSdks/tree/main/src/CentralPackageVersions)
- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11715
- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9467

## Issues
Known issues to fix before we remove the experimental flag:

- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11724
  Fixed by not logging the message
- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10311 
  Packages pinned transitively don't respect their parent's metadata
- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10126
- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11715
- [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10432

## Migration
- [ ] No one location to specify metadata like `NoWarn`
  Since [Microsoft.Build.CentralPackageVersions](https://github.com/microsoft/MSBuildSdks/tree/main/src/CentralPackageVersions) uses the `Update` guesture, it lets users specify a version for a package as well as other metadata like `NoWarn`.  However, in NuGet's CPM we only have a `<PackageVersion />` item and it wouldn't make sense to specify `NoWarn` on a package version.  Users will need to add a `<PackageReference Update="" NoWarn="1234" />` to their `Directory.Packages.props`.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet Package Manager window causes persistent WPF frame rate spike due to a runaway animation" (#11746) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
See details in the internal issue, [1496338](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_queries/edit/1496338). 

This is a consequence of a bug in WPF, where an animation does not get stop despite it being not visible.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.Commands.FuncTest.RestoreCommandTests.RestoreCommand_FrameworkImport_WarnOnAsync is flaky" (#11744) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
It's flaky, likely becausen it depends on NuGet.org.

In similar ilk like some recent fixes, we should rewrite this test to work without nuget.org.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Disable flaky test: PushCommand_PushToServer_WhenPluginReturnsAbort_ThrowsAndDoesNotFallBackToConsoleProvider" (#11745) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Package manager UI should be only updated only when there is an important state change" (#11750) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Track https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/4535#discussion_r848924794. Package manager UI should be only updated only when there is an important state change.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org" (#61) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: We announced plans to require tFA on all accounts on NuGet.org. Details in the [blog post](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/requiring-two-factor-authentication-on-nuget-org/).
